title: The Fall of Man
shortSummary: Genesis chapter 3 recounts the tragic fall of humanity through the deception of the serpent and the disobedience of Adam and Eve. This chapter explains the entrance of sin, death, and suffering into the world, as well as God's just judgment and promise of future redemption.
timeline: c. 4000 BC - The Fall of Man in the Garden of Eden

keyCharacters.name: Adam
keyCharacters.description: The first man created by God, who disobeys God's command by eating the forbidden fruit.

keyCharacters.name: Eve
keyCharacters.description: The first woman, created as a companion for Adam, who is deceived by the serpent and eats the forbidden fruit.

keyCharacters.name: The Serpent
keyCharacters.description: A cunning creature who tempts Eve to disobey God, representing Satan's role in introducing sin.

definitions.definition: Cunning or crafty; used here to describe the serpent's deceptive nature.
Hostility or opposition; refers to the ongoing conflict between the serpent and the woman’s offspring.
Heavenly beings placed by God to guard the way to the tree of life after Adam and Eve’s expulsion.
A special tree in Eden whose fruit grants eternal life, access to which is denied after the fall.

outline.heading: The Serpent’s Temptation and Eve’s Disobedience
outline.description: The serpent deceives Eve by questioning God's command, leading her to eat the forbidden fruit and share it with Adam, introducing sin into the human experience.

outline.heading: The Awareness of Sin and Attempted Covering
outline.description: Adam and Eve’s eyes are opened to their nakedness, symbolizing their newfound guilt; they attempt to hide from God and shift blame for their disobedience.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment on the Serpent, Woman, and Man
outline.description: God pronounces curses on the serpent, the woman, and the man, outlining the consequences of sin including enmity, pain in childbirth, and toil in labor.

outline.heading: The Naming of Eve and God’s Provision
outline.description: Adam names his wife Eve, acknowledging her as the mother of all living, and God provides garments of skin, symbolizing covering and grace despite sin.

outline.heading: Expulsion from Eden and Protection of the Tree of Life
outline.description: God expels Adam and Eve from the Garden to prevent eternal life in a fallen state and places cherubim and a flaming sword to guard the tree of life.

application: Recognize the subtlety of temptation and rely on God’s Word to discern truth from deception in daily life.
Confess sin openly instead of hiding or blaming others, embracing God’s forgiveness and restoration.
Understand the consequences of disobedience and submit to God’s authority as an act of faith and obedience.
Trust in God’s provision and grace even after failure, knowing He clothes and cares for His people.

keyVerses.text: And when the woman saw that the tree was good for food, and that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree to be desired to make one wise, she took of the fruit thereof, and did eat, and gave also unto her husband with her; and he did eat.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the moment of disobedience that brought sin into the world, emphasizing human responsibility in the fall.

keyVerses.text: And I will put enmity between thee and the woman, and between thy seed and her seed; it shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise his heel.
keyVerses.significance: Known as the protoevangelium, this verse promises the eventual defeat of Satan through the woman's offspring, pointing to Christ’s redemptive work.

keyVerses.text: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return unto the ground; for out of it wast thou taken: for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the consequence of sin—physical death and labor—reminding believers of human mortality and need for salvation.

keyVerses.text: Unto Adam also and to his wife did the LORD God make coats of skins, and clothed them.
keyVerses.significance: God’s provision of clothing signifies His mercy and foreshadows the need for a sacrificial covering for sin.
